text:
In July, one of the most
dominant gymnasts ever

withdrew from an
Olympic competition.

Most predicted Simone
Biles would lead Team U.S.A.
to the gold.

“The American women without
Simone Biles earn silver.”
Furious debate ensued.

“Right now, the biggest
quitter in sports is Simone
Biles.
She raised the white flag.”

“The Simone Biles story to me
is about making quitting not
only acceptable but heroic.”

Winners never quit,
and quitters never win.

We Americans are told
some version of this again
and again.
“But I’m tired, Mommy.”
“Quitter.”

Our country wasn’t
built on quitters.

As Bible-loving Americans, we
were taught that perseverance

is virtuous, and this message
finds us everywhere we go —

“(SINGING) So you gotta
hang on till tomorrow.”

— even when we try to
escape into fantasy.

“I don’t want to be the
mother of a quitter.”
We demonize quitters.
We think they’re pathetic.
“Too heavy?
Too tired?
No.
That’s all in your head.”

What if sometimes quitting
isn’t cowardly at all
but smart?

What if we’ve been wrong about
quitting our entire lives?

What if the bravest thing
you can do sometimes is quit?

I’m not talking about
quitting these things.

I mean quitting the things
you’re supposed to love
but secretly hate.
This is already happening.

We’re now living in the era
of the great resignation.

Lawyers say divorce
rates are up.

A bunch of us are
leaving our religion,

and some of us are
quitting social media, too.
“I got rid of Twitter.
I got rid of Instagram.
I got rid of Facebook.
I blocked YouTube.”

There are costs
to not quitting.

A famous one, of course,
is the Supreme Court.

If justices retired
strategically,

they could influence
their own replacements.

Like it or not, this
means R.B.G. probably

should have quit and others
on the court now, too.
Are you listening, Steve?
[CRICKETS]
Let’s be honest.

There’s a lot we wound up
starting and just never
stopped.

Economists call this
The sunk cost fallacy.

It can help explain why
you always want to stick

something out, even when
it’s not going well.

It’s the reason you keep
dating someone who you no

longer smile at or stay up
returning work emails with

“So sorry for the delay”
at the job you hate.
You’ve come this far.
How can you possibly stop now?
This is a trap.

That’s because we overlook
another economic concept,
opportunity cost.

It’s the cost of
opportunities you don’t pursue

because you’re focused on
what you’re already doing.

There is a significant
penalty that comes
with staying the course.

Powering through
is often passive.
Wait.
You’re working so hard.

How can I possibly
call you passive?

What you’re doing is
avoiding the harder thing,

which is confronting the
uncertainty of change.

You’re protecting yourself
from the fear of regret.

Worse, by continuing to barrel
through towards an inevitable

dead end, you’re cheating
yourself out of all

the opportunities
quitting might bring.

For example, for professional
women, quitting their job

and finding a new one is
often one of the best ways
to increase their earnings.

Believing you can’t quit
what you started is a trap.

This trap is something
mostly you just made up.

You’re ambitious, or you’re
anxious, or you’re addicted

to the idea of your
own importance.

Probably you’re
a little scared.
[SCREAMING]
That makes sense.

Our culture makes you
ashamed of stopping.

“So when did it become
popular to praise quitting?”

I’m not saying
quit everything.

Lots of great things
require perseverance —

our relationships, our
health, our careers —
but think about it.

Persevering shouldn’t
be a default.
It should be a choice.

Simone Biles stepped
away from competition,

even though she lost medals
and money in the short term.

After she withdrew, she
said she should have
quit gymnastics before Tokyo.

She was looking
out for herself
and playing the long game.

In doing so, she only
increased her power in her
sport and in our culture.

“Simone Biles is launching
the conversation mental health

experts say is necessary
because more people are
suffering than we know.”

For one of the most decorated
athletes in Olympic history,

walking away ultimately
increased her power

because she
invested in herself.

Quitting is not the same
as giving up, and sometimes

quitting is exactly
the recalibration

you need to figure out
what ladder you want
to climb. Or imagine rest.

Then return to what you
were doing before — better.

And some things
you can’t quit.

You may want to fire your
children half the time,
but sorry, you’re stuck.

I’m not saying you should quit
your job if you don’t have
a safety net.

Maybe you have no choice
about your life at all,

in which case, I’m sorry that
you just spent five minutes
watching this.

As we hopefully emerge
out of the pandemic,

we have a moment to decide
what we want our lives
to look like, moving forward.
Embrace the clean slate.
Don’t be a martyr to grit.
